SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Follow-up of chronic problems. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Mr. Brian Taylor is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up. It has been a little while since I last saw the patient. The patient reports he feels out of sorts lately. He does not know if it is the change in the seasons or if we are doing a lot of projects around the house and some construction on our own. He reports he is feeling out of it. He is tired and fatigued, and he feels lightheaded every once in a while. This has been going on for approximately 5 weeks. He denies any weight gain, fever, chills, dyspnea, shortness of breath, cough, or chest pain. He endorses fatigue and dizziness. Mr. Taylor also denies any other symptoms of weight gain such as swollen legs, abdominal pain, or bloating. Regarding his diet, he states he has been struggling with watching his diet. He began construction on his kitchen over labor day weekend, and it was hard to cook or prepare meals so he ate out a lot. He notes that not always the best food was good and it reeked havoc. Regarding His congestive Heart failure, he has always been good at watching his food intake, but the past year has been chaotic as he has not been as good as he had been prior to this. He states he is doing well with his medications. He continues to monitor his blood pressure regularly and assures his wife that he is staying on top of that. The Patient reports fatigue, dizziness, and lightheadedness. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Cardiovascular: Endorses fatigue. Endorses lightheadedNESS. • Respiratory: Denies chest pain, slight cramps. • Musculoskeletal: endorses weight gain. Denies fever or chills. • Neurological: Positive fatigue. • Psychiatric: Positive mood changes. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 • Constitutional: Examination of the jugular venous distention: 8 cm. Cardiovascular 3/6 systolic ejection murmur, bilaterally. Lungs 1+ pitting edema. 

RESULTS

 Echocardiogram demonstrates reduced ejection fraction of 45%. leaky valve. 1+ mitral regurgitation. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 The patient presents today with a follow- up of his chronic problem. Congestive heart Failure. • Medical Reasoning: I believe he is retaining fluid. • Additional Testing: We will order an echococardogram. • Lasix: 80 mg once a day. • Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed treatment options today. I advised him to increase his Lasix to 80 mg twice daily. He should also continue taking his lisinopril 20 mg daily. • Specialist Referrals: He should continue to record his blood pressures at home and report them to me in the patient portal if he sees they are elevated. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

The pain is mostly located in the inside of her knee. She has been putting ice on it and taking ibuprofen, but it does not help. She reports some tenderness along the medial aspect of her right knee. If she bends her knee forward or twists it a little bit, it hurts. She also has tenderness down here in her calves. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies calf pain. • Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, right calf pain, and calves pain. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 MSK: Examination of the right knee: Tenderness over the medial portion of the knee overthe medial meniscus area. No tenderness when flexing the leg or doing valgus stressing on the leg. Normal sensation. • 

RESULTS

ASSESSMENT

 • Medical Reasoning: On exam and x-ray of her left knee, there appears to be no fractures there. I do not believe this is an acute medialMeniscus sprain. • Additional Testing: We will order an MRI for further evaluation. • Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to be conservative with her treatment options. • Medical Treatment: We are going to start her on Motrin, 800 mg, every 6 hours with food. She will use crutches for the next couple of days and will follow up in 1 week. All questions were answered.

The pain is in his lower back. He took some Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used a little bit of icy heat on the spot but it did not seem to help. He feels some tingling in his toes on his right foot until about Sunday afternoon, and then that seemed to go away. There is no numbness or tingles in his legs.  • Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss. • Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain. Endorses dyspnea on exertion. • Musculoskeletal: • Neurological: Endorse right-sided pain.

RESULTS

He is compliant with his medication. • additional Testing: I recommended we increase the metformin from 1000 mg twice a day to 3000 mg twice daily. 3. Osteoarththritis. •medical Reasoning): The patient has been doing a good job of monitoring his knee. I advised him to limit his knee activity while he is on the fly and on the go. He was compliant with this and has been compliant with the recommended physical therapy. • Specialist Referrals: We can refer him to physical therapy if he does not improve.  Iron deficiency anemia.

 Christina cooper is a new patient who was referred by Diane Nelson for a long-standing iron deficiencyAnemia. The patient has been anemic since she was 13 years old. She has a history of heavy periods and underwent a hysterectomy in 1996. Her last colonoscopy was 5 to 6 years ago. She denies any issues with sedation prior to the upper endoscopy.

VITALS

 Hemoglobin: low. Hematocrit: stable. Iron: 25 mg twice daily. ferritin: Low. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 CV: Lungs: Normal. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. No tenderness in the heart or lungs. 

RESULTS

 Follow up blood work on 01/20/20 revealed low hemoglobin, stable hematocritic, and normal iron labs, although ferriton was low. She was taking ferrous sulfate, 3 500 phil- 25 mg by mouth. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 Christina Cooper is a pleasant 65-year-old female who was diagnosed with iron deficiencyanemia in 12/2019 and 12/2020 and was unable to donate blood. Her followup blood work revealed a decrease in hemoglobin and stable iron labs. A referral was sent to her hematologist for further evaluation. I have asked her to continue each dose of vitamin C found in orange juice, for the next 12 weeks, then recheck to the CBC, iron, ferritar, B12, and folate. I recommend we perform an Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat ( Egd) and a colonoscopies to assess for potential sources of anemia or gastrointestinal bleeding. If these tests are normal, we will consider capsule endoscopic. Additionally, I have recommended that she start taking her iron pills with orange juice. She should call us if she has any questions or worsening symptoms. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 New diagnosed pituitary adenoma. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for worsening headaches. He denied any trouble with headaches in the past. His past clinical history is unremarkable. The headaches tend to be worse in the morning. He describes them as a dull ache behind the eyes. They last a few hours at a time. Nothing makes them better or worse. He denies feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. He also denies any change in his vision or balance. The patient tried Tylenol a few times for the headaches, but it did not work, so he stopped. He does not take any medicines for other medical problems. He is employed as a computer programmer and has been married for 25 years. Mr. Ward denies any history of disease in his family. He has never passed out in his life. He presents today for neuro consult at the request of Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Ms. Ward reports that she is really getting fed up with the headaches. She reports that they have been going on for months and that they are located behind her eyes. She denies any fever or any kind of rash. The Patient also reports that he seems to be bumping into door frames. She denied any changes in her vision since her eyes were checked in the fall. 

PAST HISTORY

 No family history of diseases. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

 Employed as computer programmer. Denies alcohol, smoke, or use recreational drugs. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 • Constitutional: Denies fever, rash, or numbness. • Eyes: Reports headaches. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 MSK: Examination of the eyes reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No motor, motor, or sensory deficit in the upper extremities or lower extremities. visual acuity and eye movements are normal. 

VITALS

 BP: Equal and reactive. 

RESULTS

 I personally reviewed the labs dated 3/3/21 including Cbc, Unes, coagulation, and crp. All were normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH. All other results werenormal. I personally review pertinent radiology studies including MRI for the brain with contrast from 3/4/21. The Mri reveals a pituitsary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. the ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are lo- are noted. 

ASSESSMENT

 Bilateral pituitARY adenomas. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her MRI images reveal a pituitaries adenectomy. We discussed the risks and benefits of this procedure and I have recommended that she be seen by a eye doctor for a full exam and a pre-surgery visual field test. We also discussed that she should monitor after surgery to see if her vision is improving. I will get her scheduled with our surgery scheduler on the way out to get her set up. All questions were answered. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will call if she has any questions.

 1. Esophageitis. • Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with symptoms similar to esophageal edema. These have been present for 3 months and have not been relieved with medication. CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Smith Magenis syndrome. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Katherine is a 22-month-old former 34 and 3-week-old, twin with smith magenis Syndrome. She is a twin girl and a well-nourished female. The girl is slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. She has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Denies fevers or changes in appetite. Musculoskeletal: Reports orthopedic and ophthalmologist. Skin: Reports rash and ecchymosis. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 Physical exams show the well-natured female, who is slightlyFussy when examination. She utilizes milk, water, and sometimes water with juice for drinking. 

RESULTS

 Neck is slightly shorter and chunkier than her twin, which I believe is part of her syndrome. Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat are similar to her twin. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. smith MAGENIS syndrome. - Medical Reasoning: Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature. - Patient Education and Counseling: We will obtain the screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in dallas, georgia, so her follow- up should be at the town center location. - Additional Testing: Repeat kidney ultrasound. 2. Cardiovascular: I want to take a quick listen to her heart and lungs. I will also look in her ears. - medical Treatment: Complete paperwork and give instructions for the ultrasound. We will talk soon. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right wrist pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Diana Martinez is a pleasant 53-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began yesterday, when she was doing her laundry. She states that she was walking up and down the stairs when she slipped and she put her arms out to catch herself. She notes that all of a sudden her wrist started to hurt and it got real swollen. The patient reports that her pain level is 9 out of 10. She reports that she has tried applying ice and using her ACE wrap at home, but it does not help. She adds that taking ibuprofen helps a little but it is not right. She denies any numbness or tingling. She is unable to move her right wrist without extreme pain. She can feel it in her fingers, but just maybe a little bit. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Negative for fever. Musculoskeletal: Positive for wrist abduction adduction. Positive for pain on movement. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 Neck - General Examination: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit. Respiratory rate is normal at 20. Cardiovascular - Auscultation of Lungs: Clear to auscultations bilaterally. Lower extremities: palpable pulses. No lower edema. shoulders - upper extremities - normal range of movement with right wrist. 

RESULTS

 X-ray of the right wrist is obtained and reviewed today. Examination of the metacarpals reveals obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and obvious swelling and tenderness on palpation throughout. There is evidence of potential fracture feeling some bony crepitus. 

ASSESSMENT

 Right wrist colles' fracture. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. We will give her a thumb spica today and then we will brace her wrist. She will remain non-weight-bearing for 6 weeks until her surgery, at which point she will be bracing her wrist for the next 6 weeks. In the meantime, she will go to physical therapy 3 times a week to strengthen her wrist, to prevent future injury. I explained to the patient that I want her to come in for her surgery as soon as possible as she is going on a vacation in a month. She understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 1 month to check on her progress and we will discuss further treatment options.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Left shoulder pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 The patient is a 79-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain, which has been present for a few weeks. The patient states that he has been active and has been renovating his basement. He denies any specific injury, however, he notes that they have been doing a lot of work in his basement recently. He explains that he experiences pain when he tries to reach for something or lift any objects and that he does not try to reach it for anything over his head as it will really hurt. He adds that the pain is always there and then it gets worse. He states that if he attempts to put any pressure on it, the pain worsens. He reports that he is unable to lay on his left shoulder if he is laying at night as the pain becomes unbearable. He has been taking 2 extra strength Tylenol every 6 to 8 hours which has provided some relief, but he still has some pain. He does not experience any numbness or tingling in his arms or hands. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Denies left shoulder injury. Neurological: Reports left arm pain. 

VITALS

 All vital signs are within the normal limits. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavic joints. Good hand grips. Neurovascularly intact sensation in the left arm. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. 

RESULTS

 X-rays of theleft shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal no fractures. 

ASSESSMENT

 Left shoulder rotator cuff tendinopathy. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his x-rays revealed no fractures and that his symptoms are most likely due to rotators cuff tend inopathy. This means that he injured the tendons of the muscles that help make up his shoulder muscles. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the Left shoulder to be sure that there is nothing else going on with his shoulder. I am also going to refer him to physical therapy for approximately 6 to8 weeks and he may also continue to take Tylenium as needed. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection for shoulder relief. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me after he completes his physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Follow-up during neo AGIT chemotherapy. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Ms. Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage 3 nonsmile cell lung cancer who presents for follow- up during neo agit chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. She is on a combination of 2 different chemotherapies the cisplestan as well as the Eupside. She had her last treatment just a few days ago. Right now she has been able to tolerate the nausea and fatigue. She denies any nausea or vomiting. The patient reports minimal cough and sore throat. She has been eating but not as much as she normally would. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports fatigue. Denies nausea. Cardiovascular: Denies dyspnea. Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath. Neurological: Reports cough. 

VITALS

 Vitals look good, especially oxygen especially with the chemotherapy he has been getting. cough: Mild dry cough. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 Neck: Examination of the neck especially with sore throat reveals no cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy. RESPIRATORY: Regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs. ResULTS Chest x-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Lung cancer. - Medical Reasoning: The patient's chest x-rays revealed mild radiation pneumonia, which is most likely due to inflammation of the lungs. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of the diagnosis and that this is likely the cause of her cough. I advised the patient that her symptoms are mild and that she should continue with her current regimen of chemotherapy. We also discussed that she can continue to take food and fluids to prevent dehydration and any further weight loss. - Additional Testing: When she has completed her current dose of 40 grade 5 radiation, we will need to obtain repeat imaging and hopefully the tumor will shrink enough that we can surgically remove the radiation pneumons. - medical Treatment: Prescription for prednisone 40 mg daily for 5 days provided. Prescription also provided for lidocaine swish and swallow 4 times a day. Patient Agreements: the patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

 Abnormal lab work.

He denies family history of immune deficiencies and any other medical conditions. He recently traveled internationally and reports that he had a great time. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: No fever. Respiratory: No wheezes, rales. Gastrointestinal: No abdominal infections. 

VITALS

 All vital signs are within normal limits. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 Neck - General Examination: No lymph lymphadenopathy. No swollen lymph glands. Cardiovascular - Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs. Musculoskeletal - Examination: Abdomen is soft. No tenderness as I push around. 

RESULTS

 The patient's most recent lab work was reviewed and it is consistent with an iga deficiency. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Abnormal labs. - Medical Reasoning: The patient presents today with symptoms similar to an immunodeficiency. His recent labwork was also consistent with a deficiency of iga. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the nature of the diagnosis and that this is common to many people with this type of immunosuppression. I advised the patient that his body makes many different types of antibodies and that his Ziga deficiency is a little lower than normal most of the time of his entire life. I also advised him that even without knowing that he has a deficiency, he should continue to function perfectly normal. Questions were invited and answered today. - medical Treatment: We are going to order additional blood work that includes checking those other antibodies. Bring the patient in for that. The only other thing I would recommend is that if he eats and ends up needing blood products between now and when I see him next, that he tell them that he have a history of a iga deficient. Patient Agreements: the patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right elbow pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Lawrence Taylor is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for an evaluation of right elbow Pain. The onset of his elbow pain began 1 week ago, when he was doing pottery. He notes that over the past week he has had elbow pain, which he rates as the worst pain he has ever felt in his life. He rates his pain on a scale of 0 to 10, with 0 being the worst and 10 being the best. He states that the pain keeps him up at night. He denies any trauma to his arm or elbow. The patient estimates that his pain has been present for approximately 4 days. He has tried taking ibuprofen, which does not provide him with relief. He endorses that he has never injured his right elbow before. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

 The patient reports that he enjoys pottery and has been doing a lot of pottery over the last week. 

MEDICATIONS

 The patient denies any past medical history. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbowPain. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 MSK: Examination of the right elbow: Positive for pain with pain to palpation. Mild tenderness of the medial epicondyle. 

RESULTS

 X-rays of theright elbow were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal no fracture or bony abnormality. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 The patient's x-ray results are consistent with medial Epicondylitis. I advised the patient that this is caused by overuse and potential damage of tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm. He was advised to rest his arm on the table palm side up. I also advised him to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes 3 times per day. He should take ib uprofen 600 mg q.6 h with food. I want him to hold off on any type of work for the next couple of weeks. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me in 1 week to check on his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Emergency department. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 Patient reports history of hypertension, smoking, and shortness of breath. 

MEDICATIONS

 Patient reports taking Cozaar 100 mg daily, Norvasc 5 mg once daily. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance. Cardiovascular: Denied chest pain. Respiratory: DenIES shortnessof breath. Musculoskeletal: Reports ankle swelling and edema in the lower extremities. 

VITALS

 BP: 128/72. HR: 128 bpm. SpO2: 2/6. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 Neck - General Examination: No jugular venous distention. Cardiac - Auscultation of Heart: 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur, stable. Lungs are clear bilaterally. ResULTS Echocardiogram demonstrates preserved ejection fraction of 50% and normal diastolic filling. Mild to moderate mild mitral regurgitation. 

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

 1. Hypertension. - Medical Reasoning: Patient's elevated blood pressure today is likely caused by his dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension. - Patient Education and Counseling: I explained to the patient that his blood pressure was elevated in the hospital and that this was likely due to his diet. I advised him that his diet should be watched and that we can give him some advice on watching his salty foods. He was advised to document his diet as well as his medication taken. I also advised him to continue to take his medication on time and see a nutritionist as needed to help him get his diet on track. - Additional Testing: We are going to order a renal artery ultrasound to make sure that we are not missing anything. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right-sided abdominal pain. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Russell Taylor is a pleasant 69-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right-sided abdomen pain. The onset of his pain began several days ago, when he was seen by his primary care physician. He states that his doctor ordered a CT scan of his abdomen and told him that he had a kidney stone. He subsequently saw a urologist who confirmed the diagnosis and referred him to see a ureteroscopy. The patient reports that his pain radiates down into his groin, and that he can not find a comfortable position when urinating or peeing. He denies any blood in his urine, but notes that his urine sometimes looks dark. He reports taking Tylenol for pain, which has not been beneficial. He adds that he feels nauseated, but he is not vomiting. He has a history of kidney stones in the past, and notes that he has been able to pass them. He also reports positive CVA tenderness on the right flank. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Negative for fever or chills. Gastrointestinal: Positive for right flank tenderness. Musculoskeletal: Positive right flank pain. 

VITALS

 Oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. 

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

 Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation. No rebound or guarding. No peritoneal signs. There is positive Cva tenderness over the right kidney. 

RESULTS

 Ct scan of the abdomen was ordered and reviewed today. It reveals a 5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right Ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis. 

ASSESSMENT

 1. Acute nephrolithiasis 2. Kidney stone. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and CT results today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his CT scan revealed a 5 mm kidney stone in the right ureters. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. He will continue to push fluids to help facilitate urination and peeing to help pass the stone. I am going to prescribe oxycodone5 mg every six to eight hours asneeded for his pain. He can continue to alternate that with some tylenol. I will provide him with a strainer that he may use to strain his urine so that we can see the stone when it passes. We will also order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and a urine culture. I want to see him again in 1 to 2 weeks. If he is still having symptoms, we will have to discuss further treatment such as lithotripsy. We could also consider a uREteroscopies. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will contact me if he is having worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Nicolas Perez is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a non- hematochezia right foot. The onset of his symptoms began 6 weeks ago, when he put on a pair of shoes that were too tight. He first noticed burning and stinging on his right foot, but he did not think too much of it because he was walking on the pad of the bottom of his foot around his heel. He then began to notice a foul smell and his wife noticed that their dog was also smelling their socks a lot. She called the primary care doctor who got him in to see you today. He started me on some antibiotics about 6 days ago and I never had any nausea or vomiting. At one point he had to put on an extra blanket in bed because he had chills. When he started the antibiotics it started to feel pretty good, but we have now noticed that it has turned black around the outside of the wound and he is getting some cramping in his calf muscle. There was a red streak also that was coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscles. It is super super hot. He has noticed that every time he pushes that, he feels it all the way up to his knee behind his kneecap. He also noticed that he has been coughing a lot the last 2 days. The patient has noticed difficulty catching his breath when he is walking around the house. 

MEDICAL HISTORY

 Patient reports history of diabetes mellitus and neuropathy. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

 patient reports that he and his family have been hiking to charlie's Bunion. 

MEDICATIONS

 Patient reports that they have been wearing a new pair of diabetic shoes every 3 or 4 months for control. He used to be on an insulin pump and had an a1c that at one point was 13 but worked with an endocrinologist to get it down to 6 point 7 for probably 2 years. He rarely has a blood sugar that goes over 2100. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Musculoskeletal: Reports right foot ulcers. 

VITALS

 Slight fever. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 MSK: Examination of the right foot: There is a necrotic wound on the heel, approximately 2 by 2 cm. There is sloughing of the of the tissue as well as what looks like cellulitis around the area and erythemia. I do also smell the odor. Bilateral palpable pulses femorally and popliteal pulses are present. However, I do not recognize a palpable pulse dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial. 

RESULTS

 X-ray of the Right foot taken today in office does not reveal any evidence of osteomyelitis. 

ASSESSMENT

 Right foot non-healed diabetic foot Ulcer. 

PLAN

 After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his x-ray did not reveal signs of osteoarthritis. We discussed that his blood sugar levels have been fluctuating in the 3 to 4 hundreds over the past 2 weeks and that his wife alerted us to the possible cause of his elevated blood sugar level and that this is what led her to call in the Primary care physician. I has recommended that he continue his antibiotics therapy that his primary care physician put him on. We will order a test to check blood supply for the wound. We are going to perform a debridement today in the office and also perform a culture. We may have to extend or call in a new antibiotic depending on the culture. I am concerned about the redness that is moving up his leg and the swelling and pain that he have in the calf. I want to see him again in 7 days. Regarding his diabetes, I want him to continue to keep his hemoglobin A1c below 7 and to closely monitor his blood sugars since we will be doing medication therapy with antibiotics and potentially some other medications. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

 Right knee tick bite. 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

 Richard Taylor is a pleasant 69-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right kneetick bite. The onset of his symptoms began 1 week ago, however he denies any fever, chills, or other joint pain. The patient states that he has spent a lot of time out of the woods. He denies fever or chills. He does note that his knee feels warm on that spot. He describes full range of motion of his right knee and evidence of a bull's eye rash over the right knee. He has a history of being a hunter and notes that he went hunting not long ago. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

 Constitutional: Reports hypertension. Denies fevers. Musculoskeletal: Denies right knee pain. Skin: Reports right knee bull'seye rash. 

VITALS

 Vital signs look good today. Blood pressure is elevated at 132/70 mmHg. Heart rate is slow at 60 bpm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs. Temperature is normal at 98.4 degrees F. 

PHYSICAL EXAM

 Respiratory - Auscultation of Lungs: Clear to ausculture bilaterally. Right knee - Examination: There is erythema and edema as well as an area of fluctuance over the patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of Motion. 

RESULTS

 Lyme titer and western blot are within normal limits. 

ASSESSMENT

 1. Tick bite. - Medical Reasoning: Given the patient's presentation, I am concerned with possible lyme disease. - Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed treatment options for this. I explained that we could treat this early enough that we can just treat him with oral antibiotics. He was provided with doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for about 3 weeks. We also discussed the risks of intravenous antibiotics due to the possibility of ly me disease causing problems on other organs such as the heart. I advised the patient that this can cause problems on his heart if not treated appropriately. 2. Hypertension. - medical Reasoning; He is doing a good job with taking his lisinopril. - patient Education and counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue with his metformin 20 mg once a day. I also advised him to watch his sugar intake as it appears to be in the twenties. - Additional Medical Treatment: I will order a hemoglobin A1c and continue him on the metform in 1000 mg twice daily. 3. Kidney function. -medical Reasoning): The patient reports that his kidney function has been normal since his last visit approximately 2 months ago. I have ordered a basic metabolic panel to make sure that his renal function is stable. Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. 

INSTRUCTIONS

 The patient will follow up with me as soon as he leaves.
